condition.description:
Deep vein thrombosis, or DVT, is a blood clot that forms in a vein deep in the body. Most deep vein clots occur in the lower leg or thigh. If the vein swells, the condition is called thrombophlebitis. A deep vein thrombosis can break loose and cause a serious problem in the lung, called a pulmonary embolism.

Sitting still for a long time can make you more likely to get a DVT. Some medicines and disorders that increase your risk for blood clots can also lead to DVTs. Common symptoms are

  • Warmth and tenderness over the vein
  • Pain or swelling in the part of the body affected
  • Skin redness

Treatment includes medicines to ease pain and inflammation, break up clots and keep new clots from forming. Keeping the affected area raised and applying moist heat can also help. If you are taking a long car or plane trip, take a break, walk or stretch your legs and drink plenty of liquids.
condition.name: DVT

carousel_items: Thins your blood to prevent clots from forming or getting bigger. Doesn't break up existing clots.
The amount you need depends on your diet, other medical problems, and genes.
Take it exactly as instructed.
Can raise your risk of bleeding or bruising.
Requires regular blood tests to get your dose right.
Interacts with a lot of medicines and supplements. Don't start any new meds without talking to your doctor.
Eat foods containing consistent amounts of Vitamin K.
Tell your doctor immediately if you fell or if you have unusual bleeding, bruising, swelling, or changes in vision and coordination.
Get a medical bracelet so that people know you're on a blood thinner during an emergency situation.

basics.benefits_moa: Warfarin is an anticoagulant blood thinner. It lowers chemicals called clotting factors so that it's harder for your body to form blood clots.
basics.bottom_line: Warfarin is an old, cheap, and effective medicine to prevent blood clots, but it requires some monitoring, dose adjustments, and even lifestyle changes.
downsides: Raises your risk of bleeding and bruising.
Requires routine blood testing (called an INR) to see how well the medicine is working for you and to make the dose just right for you.
Many lifestyle factors can affect how well warfarin works, such as diet, alcohol, and activity level, so it's important that you try to stay consistent with your behaviors.
Lots of interactions with other drugs or supplements. Always check with your doctor or pharmacist before starting any new meds.

downsides_processed.orig: Raises your risk of bleeding and bruising.
Requires routine blood testing (called an INR) to see how well the medicine is working for you and to make the dose just right for you.
Many lifestyle factors can affect how well warfarin works, such as diet, alcohol, and activity level, so it's important that you try to stay consistent with your behaviors.
Lots of interactions with other drugs or supplements. Always check with your doctor or pharmacist before starting any new meds.

upsides: Oral blood-thinning medicine that prevents blood clots from forming or getting bigger.

Prevents complications of blood clots that can cause extreme discomfort or death. Examples include stroke (blood clots in the brain), pulmonary embolism (blood clots in the lungs causing trouble breathing), or deep vein thrombosis (blood clots in the legs causing pain and blood vessel damage).
Has an antidote, Vitamin K, in case of a major accidental bleeding.
Warfarin has been around for a long time, so we know a lot about how well it works and what the risks are.

The amount you need depends on your diet, other medical problems, and genes.
Take it exactly as instructed.

risks_warnings.title: Life threatening bleeding
risks_warnings.description: Warfarin is a blood thinner that makes it harder for your blood to clot. Your body may not be able to stop bleeds the way it normally does. Regular monitoring through blood tests, taking the exact amount as instructed, and having a consistent diet can lower your risk of bleeding. Let your doctor know about any persistent or frequent bleeding or bruising, pink urine, red or coffee-ground like stools. If you are bleeding a lot for more than 15 minutes, have a bruise that is getting bigger instead of better, or have fallen and hit your head, go get immediate medical help. In the hospital, doctors can give you a medicine that can reverse the effects of Warfarin.

description_processed.orig: Warfarin is a blood thinner that makes it harder for your blood to clot. Your body may not be able to stop bleeds the way it normally does. Regular monitoring through blood tests, taking the exact amount as instructed, and having a consistent diet can lower your risk of bleeding. Let your doctor know about any persistent or frequent bleeding or bruising, pink urine, red or coffee-ground like stools. If you are bleeding a lot for more than 15 minutes, have a bruise that is getting bigger instead of better, or have fallen and hit your head, go get immediate medical help. In the hospital, doctors can give you a medicine that can reverse the effects of Warfarin.

risks_warnings.title: Dying skin or tissue needing surgery or amputation
risks_warnings.description: Warfarin can cause this rare, but serious, condition where the skin or tissue is dying from poor blood flow. The risk is highest in the first few days to week 8 of starting Warfarin. Let your doctor know about any unusual changes in color of your extremities, breasts, or penis. Your doctor will then find you another blood-thinning medicine to replace Warfarin.

description_processed.orig: Warfarin can cause this rare, but serious, condition where the skin or tissue is dying from poor blood flow. risks_warnings.title: Harm to fetus
risks_warnings.description: Warfarin causes birth defects. If you're considering having a baby, talk to your doctor about alternative medications.

carousel_items: Make sure to change where you inject Heparin every time.
Don't take aspirin or other anti-inflammatory medications without talking to your doctor first.
You will have to do regular blood draws or labs to make sure that Heparin is working for you.

basics.benefits_moa: Heparin is an anticoagulant that binds with proteins and platelets to stop blood clots from being made and traveling to the brain, heart, and lungs.
basics.bottom_line: Heparin is a good anticoagulant that prevents blood clots. However, you'll need to get frequent blood tests to make sure it's working well.
downsides: You'll need to get labs/blood draws done on a regular basis to make sure the drug is working and to make sure you don't get unexpected side effects.
You can be at higher risk for bleeding or clotting while taking Heparin compared to other anticoagulants.

downsides_processed.orig: You'll need to get labs/blood draws done on a regular basis to make sure the drug is working and to make sure you don't get unexpected side effects.
You can be at higher risk for bleeding or clotting while taking Heparin compared to other anticoagulants.

upsides: Safe to use in pregnancy and if you're breast feeding.
There are other medications that can help stop unexpected bleeding while taking Heparin.
Usually used in the hospital, but can be given at home too.

upsides_processed.orig: Safe to use in pregnancy and if you're breast feeding.
There are other medications that can help stop unexpected bleeding while taking Heparin.
Usually used in the hospital, but can be given at home too.

drugs.name: Heparin

carousel_items_processed.orig: Make sure to change where you inject Heparin every time.
Don't take aspirin or other anti-inflammatory medications without talking to your doctor first.
You will have to do regular blood draws or labs to make sure that Heparin is working for you.

risks_warnings.title: Unusual bleeding
risks_warnings.description: There are certain medicines that can significantly change the amount of Heparin in your body, putting you at risk for bleeding or making the drug less effective. Let your doctor know about other prescription and non-prescription medicines you're taking, especially other medicines that affect bleeding risk like aspirin and NSAIDs.

description_processed.orig: There are certain medicines that can significantly change the amount of Heparin in your body, putting you at risk for bleeding or making the drug less effective. Let your doctor know about other prescription and non-prescription medicines you're taking, especially other medicines that affect bleeding risk like aspirin and NSAIDs.

risks_warnings.title: Clotting problems
risks_warnings.description: Heparin shouldn't be used in people who have a history of heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT). HIT can happen when heparin is given to a person and their immune system creates antibodies that activate platelets, causing significant unexpected clotting. Laboratory tests can confirm this is happening and all heparin-related treatments need to be stopped immediately.

description_processed.orig: Heparin shouldn't be used in people who have a history of heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT). HIT can happen when heparin is given to a person and their immune system creates antibodies that activate platelets, causing significant unexpected clotting. Laboratory tests can confirm this is happening and all heparin-related treatments need to be stopped immediately.

carousel_items: Rotate the spot where you inject Lovenox every day.
While on this, it can take longer to stop bleeding and you are more likely to bruise or bleed more easily.
Avoid taking certain anti-inflammatory drugs (like NSAIDs) because they can make you more likely to bleed.
Can cause swelling in your legs, diarrhea, and nausea.

basics.benefits_moa: Lovenox is an anticoagulant that prevents certain blood-clotting proteins from working. By stopping blood clots from forming, there's a lower chance of having a stroke or blood clots travel to your lungs.
basics.bottom_line: Lovenox is a good anticoagulant that reduces the risk of death or bleeding, and blood clots are less likely to happen. However, it is only available as an injection which isn't great if you're afraid of needles.
downsides: It is only available as an injection, so it's not great if you're afraid of needles.
While surprise bleeding episodes can be treated while taking Lovenox, they won't completely work.
It doesn't work as well as other medications for "thinning the blood" if you are overweight, underweight, or if you have kidney disease.

downsides_processed.orig: It is only available as an injection, so it's not great if you're afraid of needles.
While surprise bleeding episodes can be treated while taking Lovenox, they won't completely work.
It doesn't work as well as other medications for "thinning the blood" if you are overweight, underweight, or if you have kidney disease.

upsides: In a study that compared Lovenox to other medications used to stop blood clots, there was a lower risk of clots coming back, with similar rates of major bleeding and mortality.
You don't need to go in for lab tests to check whether it's working, unlike other medications like warfarin that require regular blood draws.
Available in generic so it can be cheaper than other "blood thinners".
Good option if you're pregnant or have cancer.

upsides_processed.orig: In a study that compared Lovenox to other medications used to stop blood clots, there was a lower risk of clots coming back, with similar rates of major bleeding and mortality.
You don't need to go in for lab tests to check whether it's working, unlike other medications like warfarin that require regular blood draws.
Available in generic so it can be cheaper than other "blood thinners".
Good option if you're pregnant or have cancer.

userStories.tip: Expensive, can cause bleeding (locally and remote)

carousel_items_processed.orig: Rotate the spot where you inject Lovenox every day.

risks_warnings.title: Blood clot in the spine
risks_warnings.description: You're more likely to have a blood clot in the spine if you're taking Lovenox and are getting either a spinal tap or an epidural. Call your doctor immediately if you notice pain or a tingling or burning sensation, numbness, weakness, or inability to urinate.
risk_factors: Getting anesthesia in the spine (epidural anesthesia)
Taking NSAIDs or other blood thinning medicines

risks_warnings.title: Increased risk of stroke or increased risk of blood clots
risks_warnings.description: Don't stop taking Lovenox before your doctor tells you to. You could be at a higher risk for stroke or heart attack, especially if you have certain heart rate problems, like atrial fibrillation. Talk to your doctor if you're interested in stopping this medicine or switching to a different one.

carousel_items: Xarelto is an anticoagulant, so it's important not to miss a dose. Don't stop taking this medication without talking to your doctor first.
When taking Xarelto, you can bleed more easily, so use a soft toothbrush and an electric razor to avoid cutting yourself.
Take Xarelto with food and a full glass of water.
You can crush the tablets and mix with applesauce.

clock.tip: Take with food to work faster.

basics.benefits_moa: Xarelto is an anticoagulant that stops the formation of blood clots.
basics.bottom_line: Xarelto is a good medication for preventing blood clots. It doesn't require regular blood tests or changing doses often. It can be expensive and there's no way to reverse the medication's effects.
downsides: Xarelto can increase your risk of bleeding. Call your doctor right away if there is blood in your phlegm, urine, or stool (look for black, tarry stools).
Xarelto isn't available as a generic medication.
There are no antidotes to stop bleeding caused by taking too much Xarelto.

downsides_processed.orig: Xarelto can increase your risk of bleeding. Call your doctor right away if there is blood in your phlegm, urine, or stool (look for black, tarry stools).
Xarelto isn't available as a generic medication.
There are no antidotes to stop bleeding caused by taking too much Xarelto.

upsides: Studies have shown that Xarelto works just as well as other blood thinners (anticoagulants) in preventing strokes and reducing bleeding.
Xarelto doesn't require regular blood testing or frequent dose adjustments.
Xarelto doesn't have as many food interactions as compared to other anticoagulants like warfarin (Coumadin).

upsides_processed.orig: Studies have shown that Xarelto works just as well as other blood thinners (anticoagulants) in preventing strokes and reducing bleeding.
Xarelto doesn't require regular blood testing or frequent dose adjustments.
Xarelto doesn't have as many food interactions as compared to other anticoagulants like warfarin (Coumadin).

userStories.tip: Works well for me, saves many trips to control Coumadin which I used before.  I think it is safe, my doctors say it is.  Is not cheap but Medicare covers it with $33 co pay (per month).
Took about a week for the skin itching to subside. Skin dryness continued for another month or so but easily relieved with lotion. No other problems to report. Way better experience than warfarin!

Take with food. My skin started itching like crazy all over for the first week. That eventually subsided but skin is very dry all the time now. Have to coat entire body with shae butter day and night to treat the dry skin.
Taking it with food may make it easier on your stomach.  Tendency to bruise lessens with time.
userStories.identifier: retiree with atrial flutter and arthriti

drugs.name: Xarelto

carousel_items_processed.orig: Xarelto is an anticoagulant, so it's important not to miss a dose. Don't stop taking this medication without talking to your doctor first.
When taking Xarelto, you can bleed more easily, so use a soft toothbrush and an electric razor to avoid cutting yourself.
Take Xarelto with food and a full glass of water.
You can crush the tablets and mix with applesauce.

risks_warnings.title: Blood clots and stroke
risks_warnings.description: Don't stop taking Xarelto until your doctor tells you to, since stopping too early can put you at greater risk for getting blood clots or stroke, especially if you're not being switched to another blood thinner to continue treatment. Talk to your doctor first if you want to stop this medication. Also, Xarelto isn't right for you if you have an artificial heart valve because it can increase your risk of blood clots or stroke.

description_processed.orig: Don't stop taking Xarelto until your doctor tells you to, since stopping too early can put you at greater risk for getting blood clots or stroke, especially if you're not being switched to another blood thinner to continue treatment. Talk to your doctor first if you want to stop this medication. Also, Xarelto isn't right for you if you have an artificial heart valve because it can increase your risk of blood clots or stroke.

risks_warnings.title: Blood clot in the spine
risks_warnings.description: You're at greater risk for a blood clot in the spine if you're taking Xarelto and you get either a spinal tap or an epidural. A blod clot in your spine can cause paralysis. Call your doctor immediately if you notice pain or a tingling or burning sensation, numbness, weakness, or incontinence.
risk_factors: Getting anesthesia in the spine (epidural anesthesia)

description_processed.orig: You're at greater risk for a blood clot in the spine if you're taking Xarelto and you get either a spinal tap or an epidural. A blod clot in your spine can cause paralysis. Call your doctor immediately if you notice pain or a tingling or burning sensation, numbness, weakness, or incontinence.

risks_warnings.title: Unusual bleeding
risks_warnings.description: As with all blood thinners, it will take a little longer for your blood to clot if you're bleeding and on Xarelto. Call your doctor if you notice bleeding that won't stop, a bruise that won't go away or gets worse, pink or brown urine, bright red or dark tarry stool, nose bleeds, or coughing up blood.
risk_factors: Taking NSAIDs, aspirin, or other blood-thinning medicines

description_processed.orig: As with all blood thinners, it will take a little longer for your blood to clot if you're bleeding and on Xarelto. Call your doctor if you notice bleeding that won't stop, a bruise that won't go away or gets worse, pink or brown urine, bright red or dark tarry stool, nose bleeds, or coughing up blood.

risks_warnings.title: Increased side effects
risks_warnings.description: Xarelto is processed by the kidney and liver. If you have kidney or liver problems, talk to your doctor about possibly switching to a different medicine to prevent increased risk for side effects.

description_processed.orig: Xarelto is processed by the kidney and liver. If you have kidney or liver problems, talk to your doctor about possibly switching to a different medicine to prevent increased risk for side effects.

carousel_items: Using low doses (81mg) of aspirin every day can lower your risk of heart attack and stroke, but it isn't good for everyone. Only take aspirin daily if your doctor recommends it.
Higher aspirin doses can be used to treat occasional pain, swelling, and fever. Using ibuprofen or acetaminophen (Tylenol) instead can lower your risk of serious bleeding.
Take with food to lower the chance of an upset stomach.
Don't use for kids younger than 18 years old.
Stop taking this right away and tell your doctor if you have ringing in your ears, unusual bleeding, or nausea or vomiting that doesn't go away.

clock.tip: Take with food or milk to lower stomach upset.

basics.benefits_moa: Aspirin is a salicylate and non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID). It blocks the inflammation process in your body, which relieves swelling and pain. It also prevents blood platelets from forming clots, which thins your blood.
basics.bottom_line: A low dose of Aspirin (81mg) every day can protect your heart, but it's not the best medicine to take for pain, swelling, or fever.
downsides: Not a preferred medication for treating pain, swelling, or fever due to its high risk of bleeding.
NSAIDs (like ibuprofen and naproxen) and acetaminophen (Tylenol) are better for treating pain and fever thank aspirin.
Aspirin raises your risk of bleeding, especially when used with other blood thinner medications like warfarin (Coumadin).
Studies show that using higher doses of Aspirin (162 mg or more) every day raises your risk of stomach bleeding and doesn't provide any additional heart protection.

downsides_processed.orig: Not a preferred medication for treating pain, swelling, or fever due to its high risk of bleeding.
NSAIDs (like ibuprofen and naproxen) and acetaminophen (Tylenol) are better for treating pain and fever thank aspirin.
Aspirin raises your risk of bleeding, especially when used with other blood thinner medications like warfarin (Coumadin).
Studies show that using higher doses of Aspirin (162 mg or more) every day raises your risk of stomach bleeding and doesn't provide any additional heart protection.

upsides: When taking low doses (81 mg) every day, aspirin provides protection for your heart and prevents heart attacks and stroke.
Used in higher doses to relieve pain, swelling, and fever.
Available over-the-counter in drugstores by itself and in combination with other cold and flu medications.

upsides_processed.orig: When taking low doses (81 mg) every day, aspirin provides protection for your heart and prevents heart attacks and stroke.
Used in higher doses to relieve pain, swelling, and fever.
Available over-the-counter in drugstores by itself and in combination with other cold and flu medications.

drugs.one_liner: Relieves pain, fever, and inflammation. Protects your heart and thins blood.

userStories.tip: research and understand the actual reason to take this medicine, as well as any medicine - than it will be helpful. Don't take it "just because". High quality Aspirin (e.g. Bayer) is much better (better effect without harming)

risks_warnings.title: Brain damage or death from Reye's Syndrome
risks_warnings.description: Aspirin use is linked to a condition called Reye's syndrome that causes liver and brain swelling. This is rare but very serious. Let your doctor know about any nausea, vomiting, unusually low energy, or changes in behavior.

description_processed.orig: Aspirin use is linked to a condition called Reye's syndrome that causes liver and brain swelling. This is rare but very serious. Let your doctor know about any nausea, vomiting, unusually low energy, or changes in behavior.

risks_warnings.title: Stomach bleeding
risks_warnings.description: Aspirin can cause serious problems including inflammation, bleeding, and ulcers in the stomach or intestines. The longer you take Aspirin, the higher the risk is. If you notice blood or a dark/black color in your stool, tell your doctor right away.
risk_factors: History of stomach bleeding or ulcers
Taking aspirin, NSAIDs, or blood thinners
Drinking more than 3 alcoholic beverages a day

description_processed.orig: Aspirin can cause serious problems including inflammation, bleeding, and ulcers in the stomach or intestines. The longer you take Aspirin, the higher the risk is. If you notice blood or a dark/black color in your stool, tell your doctor right away.

risks_warnings.title: Serious allergic reactions
risks_warnings.description: Rarely, Aspirin can cause serious allergic reactions. These reactions can make it difficult to breathe or can cause a severe rash that can be life threatening. Get medical help immediately if you develop a skin rash, fever, swelling, or have trouble breathing.

description_processed.orig: Rarely, Aspirin can cause serious allergic reactions. These reactions can make it difficult to breathe or can cause a severe rash that can be life threatening. Get medical help immediately if you develop a skin rash, fever, swelling, or have trouble breathing.

risks_warnings.title: Harm to unborn babies
risks_warnings.description: Aspirin can cause birth defects. Don't use Aspirin while pregnant. If you're considering having a baby, talk to your doctor about alternative medications.

description_processed.orig: Aspirin can cause birth defects. Don't use Aspirin while pregnant. If you're considering having a baby, talk to your doctor about alternative medications.
